  • Sep 01 2015

    Visualizing My Spotify History

A recent trip to the Boston MFA inspired me to try making more art for art‚Äôs sake. I‚Äôve never been particularly crafty with a pencil or paint brush so I decided my artistic medium would have to be digital. I‚Äôve been fascinated by generative art (the dot is black has always been a quality source for interesting pieces) so I thought I would take a whack at it.

Wikipedia says generative art must be created partially or entirely using an autonomous system, but I prefer Anders Hoff‚Äôs definition of the art form:

‚ÄúI would argue that it does not really matter whether you are generating characters, dialogue or environments for a computer game, geometry as part of a building, digital or analogue art, a musical composition, or a poem. In all cases you are using a system of some kind to help you along. Either towards a specific goal, some unidentified result, or somewhere in-between. To me the main point is usually to experiment with a small system that consists of a set of relatively simple rules.‚Äù

With that in mind, I set out to see what I could create. While I enjoy the pieces I‚Äôve seen, I found a lot of generative art lacked color. As a personal fan of color, I knew I wanted to somehow include color in my piece. This led me to a question: how would a color describe itself?

Without the ability to have personal discussions with colors, I opted to use a color‚Äôs own codified representation (specifically the binary representation of a color‚Äôs hex code) to generate each color‚Äôs pattern in the piece. Doing so led to the piece above.

Feel free to play around with it and let me know if you have any thoughts on it! Is this generative art? Is there a greater meaning behind this piece? Am I just a hack making pretty pictures? Let me know and I‚Äôll let you know if I agree!
